Title:
First Report of Powdery Mildew Caused by Erysiphe quercicola
on mandarine in Viet Nam
Keywords:
Powdery mildew, Erysiphe quercicola, mandarine, Viet
Nam
Abstract:
Mandarine (Citrus reticulata) is perennial fruit-tree with
high economic value by which poor farmers in Northern mountain of Viet
Nam would become the wealthy. Since 2009, powdery mildew has been
observed on this host plant mainly from Feb to May in many valleys of
Bac Son, Lang Son. This hyperparasite fungi covers on both sides of
young and medium leaves of mandarine trees. The heavily infected trees
have often had defoliated or deformed young leave. This would decline in
capability of photosynthesis. Moreover, this fungi also covered total
surface of young fruits in 0.5 cm diameter period and caused them being
falled in a great number. As a result, fruit yield of mandarine could be
reduced even 80% if left without timely treatment. Two representative
specimens were deposited in the PPRI Herbarium (Accession Nos. PPRI-
PM007 and PPRI- PM008). Conidiophores were (60.5-)63 -101 (-106) µm
long. Foot-cells of conidiophores were (25-)27.5-35(-37.5) x 7.5-10 µm
long. Conidia produced singly has ellipsoid or ovoid shape without
fibrosin bodies, measured (27.5-)32.5-40(-42.5) x 15-20 µm with a
length/width ratio of (1.6-)1.9-2.3. Appressoria on mycelium has lobe or
multi/ opposited lobed shape. Conidia germinated with Extensitubus
subtype of Pseudoidium type germ tubes. No chasmothecia were found. The
morphological characteristics were consistent with descriptions of
Erysiphe quercicola Takamatsu & Braun 2007 (Braun and Cook 2012). To
confirm the identity of the causal fungus, the complete ITS region of
rDNA from isolates PPRI- PM007 and PPRI- PM008 were amplified by primer
pairs ITS1/ P3 (White et al. 1990; Kusaba and Tsuge 1995) and directly
sequenced. The resulting sequences were deposited in GenBank (Accession
Nos. KM260691, KM260692, respectively. Moreover, the domains D1 and D2
of 28S rRNA from these above isolates were also amplified by primer
pairs PM3 (Takamatsu and Kano, 2001)/ TW14 for 1st PCR and NL1/ TW14 for
2nd PCR and direct sequenced by NL1, NLP2 (Mori et al., 2000). The
resulting sequences were deposited in GenBank (Accession Nos. KM260673,
KM260674, respectively). BLAST searchs of these sequences showed 99 %
identity with E. quercicola isolate from Quercus crispula, Anacardium
occidentale (AB292691, AB237786). Powdery mildew on these samples from
Viet Nam belongs to E. quercicola group with bootstrap values support,
63% and 60%, in MP phylogenic trees based on analysing ITS and 28S rRNA
sequences respectively by PAUP. Pathogenicity was confirmed by gently
pressing diseased leaves of mandarine tree onto 7 to 14 day-old leaves
of five two-year-old seedlings of C. reticulata, traditional variety of
Bac Son district, Lang Son province in a glass house maintained at 26 to
28ºC. Five noninoculated seedlings were used as controls. Inoculated
leaves developed symptoms after 10-12 days, whereas the control plants
remained symptomless. The fungus present on the inoculated leaves was
morphologically identical to that observed on the original diseased
leaves, with the same ITS sequence following the PCR protocol described
above, fulfilling Kochs postulates. E. quercicola has host range and
distribution widespread in tropical and subtropical Africa, Asia and
South America such as Quercus sp. in Japan, Citrus sinensis in Malaysia,
Mangifera indica in Australia (Braun and Cook 2012). To our knowledge,
this is the first report of powdery mildew caused by E. quercicola on C.
reticulata in Viet Nam. The yield and quality of mandarine fruits has
been suffering heavy losses due to this hyperparasite fungi.
